articles.headline: Drought Spreads Pain From Florida to Arizona
articles.snippet: A drought that some say could rival the Dust Bowl has spread from Florida to Arizona.
articles.abstract: A drought that some say could rival the Dust Bowl has spread from Florida to Arizona.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLQUITT, Ga. — The heat and the drought are so bad in this southwest corner of Georgia that hogs can barely eat. Corn, a lucrative crop with a notorious thirst, is burning up in fields. Cotton plants are too weak to punch through soil so dry it might as well be pavement.
articles.byline: By Kim Severson and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Debt Contagion Threatens Italy
articles.snippet: A struggle between Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and his finance minister is threatening to make Italy’s economy a liability.
articles.abstract: A struggle between Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and his finance minister is threatening to make Italy’s economy a liability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout Europe’s debt crisis, Italy has largely managed to steer clear of the troubles that have engulfed its profligate Mediterranean neighbors.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: British Tabloid Sought Phone Data of Investigators
articles.snippet: After Scotland Yard began an inquiry into hacking by The News of the World in 2006, investigators found that their own messages had been hacked.
articles.abstract: After Scotland Yard began an inquiry into hacking by The News of the World in 2006, investigators found that their own messages had been hacked.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shortly after Scotland Yard began its initial criminal inquiry of phone hacking by The News of the World in 2006, five senior police investigators discovered that their own cellphone messages had been targeted by the tabloid and had most likely been listened to.
articles.byline: By Don Van Natta Jr. and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Bank’s Deal Means More Will Lose Their Homes
articles.snippet: As part of its $8.5 billion settlement with investors, Bank of America will turn over the work on tens of thousands of troubled mortgages to smaller servicers.
articles.abstract: As part of its $8.5 billion settlement with investors, Bank of America will turn over the work on tens of thousands of troubled mortgages to smaller servicers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Bank of America’s most distressed borrowers could be evicted and lose their homes more quickly as a result of a proposed settlement between the bank, which is the country’s largest mortgage servicer, and investors in its troubled mortgage securities.

articles.headline: A Small City’s Depleted Pension Fund Rattles Rhode Island
articles.snippet: Central Falls, R.I., cannot afford to pay its pension benefits, but a bankruptcy could set off a chain reaction that might put the state itself on the brink.
articles.abstract: Central Falls, R.I., cannot afford to pay its pension benefits, but a bankruptcy could set off a chain reaction that might put the state itself on the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: The small city of Central Falls, R.I., appears to be headed for a rare municipal bankruptcy filing, and state officials are rushing to keep its woes from overwhelming the struggling state.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Family of Robert F. Kennedy Rethinks His Place at Library
articles.snippet: As archivists prepare to make public 63 boxes of Robert F. Kennedy’s papers at the John F. Kennedy Library, his family members are having second thoughts about where they should be housed.
articles.abstract: As archivists prepare to make public 63 boxes of Robert F. Kennedy’s papers at the John F. Kennedy Library, his family members are having second thoughts about where they should be housed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As archivists prepare to make public 63 boxes of Robert F. Kennedy’s papers at the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston, his family members are having second thoughts about where they should be housed and are considering moving them elsewhere because they believe that the presidential library has not done enough to honor the younger brother’s legacy.
articles.byline: By Adam Clymer and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: Obama Grasping Centrist Banner in Debt Impasse
articles.snippet: President Obama has been casting himself as a pragmatic centrist as negotiators try to reach a deal on the budget.
articles.abstract: President Obama has been casting himself as a pragmatic centrist as negotiators try to reach a deal on the budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama made no apparent headway on Monday in his attempt to forge a crisis-averting budget deal, but he put on full display his effort to position himself as a pragmatic centrist willing to confront both parties and address intractable problems.

articles.headline: Assassination in Afghanistan Creates a Void
articles.snippet: A family associate shot Ahmed Wali Karzai, a provincial council chairman, at close range, friends said.
articles.abstract: A family associate shot Ahmed Wali Karzai, a provincial council chairman, at close range, friends said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ahmed Wali Karzai, the powerful half brother of Afghanistan’s president, was assassinated Tuesday, removing from the political scene a divisive power broker who was accused of corruption and alienated the American military, but whose connections and ruthlessness made him a critical force in volatile southern Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Scott Shane

articles.headline: With Sonic, G.M. Stands Automaking on Its Head
articles.snippet: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers are cooperating to build the Sonic subcompact at a smaller plant using new methods while paying lower wages to most workers.
articles.abstract: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers are cooperating to build the Sonic subcompact at a smaller plant using new methods while paying lower wages to most workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich. — The only subcompact car being built on American soil will soon roll out of an assembly plant here in suburban Detroit that is as unusual as the car itself.
